channel.title: Thoughts on The Arboreal Repository
channel.description: Recent content in Thoughts on The Arboreal Repository

item.title: The Puzzle Paradox
item.description: Reflecting on Challenges After doing so many challenges from pwn.college and picoCTF, I’ve had some thoughts about the enjoyment of puzzles. This is certainly a great oversimplifications, but there are the types of people that just like having the solution and don’t care much for the puzzle. Whether it’s out of a lack of tolerance for frustration or lack of patience or just preference for the rush of coming upon the solution, there are some people who just want to complete the task.

item.title: Healthy Housing: Quality, Safety, Accessibility (Open Data Syracuse pt. 2)
item.description: The Topic The topic for the Syracuse Open Data challenge has been announced. This round the theme will be “Healthy Housing: Quality, Safety, Accessibility.” They’re listed relevant Open Data Syracuse data sets: Syracuse Rental Registry Code Violations Vacant Properties Permit Requests Assessment Final Tax Roll 2024 Syracuse Parcel Map 2027 As well as some potentially useful sources for additional data sets: NYS Unified Court System- Statewide Landlord Tenant Eviction Dashboard CNY Vitals Pro (Source of data and visualizations for CNY Neighborhood topics) Zillow Real Estate Housing data and API’s Apartmentes.

item.title: Core Values Activity
item.description: Repost of my Core Values Activity - originally posted on 2024-06-16 1. Core Values and Core Principles Activity Guide Core Values Activity Tracks Part 1. Core Values Journey (~50 minutes) Part 2. Core Values Circle (For Teams) Introduction Regrouping Initial Picks - 20 Chosen Throw Everything on the Board Grouping The Method: Revise, Combine, Delete The Journey Grouping 1st Toll Round 1 2nd Toll Round 2 3rd Toll Round 3 4th Toll Round 4 5th Toll Round 5 Final Toll 2.

item.title: picoCTF Medium Challenges
item.description: A Step Up I’ve completed a couple of the medium-graded picoCTF challenges so far, and it’s a noticeable step up in difficulty. Perhaps it was due to my first attempt being in my weakest category, but the knowledge base required for this level of challenge seems to be slightly beyond where I am. After switching to the ‘General Skills’ category I had a bit better luck, but was definitely pushed harder than I was by several of the last easy challenges.

item.title: picoCTF Challenge Count
item.description: Challenge Count Even though they’ve just been the easy challenges so far, I feel like I’ve been learning a lot from the picoCTF challenges I’ve completed. In the practice section, they have many challenges graded easy, medium, and hard available to complete. At posting one challenge write up each day, getting through the easy challenges will take me to the beginning of November, the medium challenges will take me through mid-May, and the hard challenges will take me to almost the end of July.

item.title: Capture the Flag - Intro
item.description: Introduction Capture the Flag is a means of teaching cybersecurity principles through practical games. Players either try to find flags (often text strings) either held by the event host or other teams using various tools and techniques in order to win. (source Wikipedia) The game originated at DEF CON, but after learning that there are a few online platforms to play and learn, I thought it would be fun to try it out.

item.title: "The Arboreal Repository"
item.description: Recent Realizations At the time of writing I’m only a little more than 4 months into my all-consuming focus on coding, but I’m learning a lot quickly. I started my learning acceleration with a one-day, six-hour workshop with the University of Oregon data services department covering basic R in late March. The skills I learned in that workshop served as the foundation for the more powerful data processing that further amplified my primary career.
